questions.text: A therapist discusses the sexual response cycle with a patient. Which of the following statements is false about the sexual response cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: The excitement stage involves increased blood pressure and heart rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Males experience swelling of the glans and testes during the plateau stage.

options.label: C
options.text: Females experience contractions of the vagina during orgasm.

options.label: D
options.text: Both genders have a refractory period after orgasm.

questions.correct_answer: D. Both genders have a refractory period after orgasm.
questions.explanation:
Phases of the sexual response cycle

Desire phase

  • Consists of sex fantasies and the desire to have sex
  • Associated disorder: Hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD)

FDA drug approved to treat HSDD in premenopausal women

  • Flibanserin- Partial 5HT1A agonist, oral drug
  • Bremelanotide- Melanocortin receptor agonist, subcutaneous injection)

Excitement Stage
  • Muscles tense, heart rate and blood pressure increase. (Option A ruled out)
  • Males: Penis becomes erect.
  • Females: Vaginal walls become moist and wider; clitoris enlarges.
  • Associated disorder: Male erectile dysfunction, Female Sexual arousal disorder

Plateau Stage
  • Breathing becomes faster; muscles continue to tense.
  • Males: Glans swell; testes enlarge. (Option B ruled out)
  • Females: Outer vagina contracts; clitoris retracts.

Orgasm Stage
  • Neuromuscular tension releases.
  • Males: Penis contracts, ejaculating sperm and semen.
  • Females: Vagina contracts rhythmically. (Option C ruled out)
  • Associated disorder: Female orgasmic disorder, premature ejaculation, delayed ejaculation.

Resolution Stage
  • The body gradually returns to its resting state.
  • Males: Penis shrinks; includes a refractory period where further arousal is not possible.
  • Females: No refractory period; can become aroused again quickly.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man reports to his doctor that he is having difficulty achieving an erection during intercourse. He mentions this issue has been ongoing for the past year, despite having previously enjoyed a healthy sex life. Which statement about his condition is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Erectile dysfunction is common in all ageing men.

options.label: B
options.text: Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors can be safely used with nitrates.

options.label: C
options.text: Situational erectile disorder means he can achieve erections in certain situations.

options.label: D
options.text: Organic Erectile Dysfunction occurs in men with relationship issues.

questions.correct_answer: C. Situational erectile disorder means he can achieve erections in certain situations.
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Erectile Dysfunction

Pharmacotherapy

Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (PDE-5 inhibitors)

  • Nitric oxide enhancers- facilitates blood flow into the penis and enhances erection.
  • Drugs- Sildenafil, tadalafil, vardenafil and Avanafil.
  • Not used along with organic nitrates- Can cause sudden fall in blood pressure and can be fatal. (Option B)

Other medications:

  • Oral phentolamine: May reduce sympathetic tone and relax muscles of corpora cavernosa and subsequently improve the erection.
  • Alprostadil contains naturally occurring prostaglandin E (vasodilating agent).
  • Alprostadil- Directly injected into corpora cavernosa or given intraurethral through a cannula as a pellet.

Psychotherapy

Dual sex therapy:

  • It was derived by Masters and Johnson.
  • It is also effective for other sexual disorders as well.
  • It means it treats the couple (not individual). Both the partners are involved in the treatment.
  • Couples are taught: To improve their communication and Exercises to increase sensory awareness.

Sensate focus exercises:

  • It has two stages:
  • Non-genital sensate focus: Couples should touch, rub, or kiss each other body parts excluding breasts, and genitals
  • Genital sensate focus: Stage II Involves only breasts and genitals. Subsequently, the couple can engage in complete intercourse.
  • Purpose of exercises is to make the couple aware that pleasure can be given and received by methods other than sexual intercourse (penetration).

Others:

  • Behavioral therapy
  • Hypnotherapy
  • Psychoanalysis

questions.text: A 30-year-old man visits his doctor expressing frustration with his sexual performance. He reports that he ejaculates within 30 seconds of vaginal penetration, which has caused distress in his relationship. Which of the following treatments is not typically used for premature ejaculation?

A 32-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with concerns about her inability to achieve orgasm during sexual activity with her partner. She reports that this has been an ongoing issue for the past 8 months and is causing distress in her relationship. She has normal sexual desire but is unable to reach orgasm despite adequate stimulation She has no history of medical conditions or medication use that might explain these symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the DSM-5 criteria?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Recurrent or persistent inhibition of female orgasm, as manifested by delay in, or absence of orgasm after a normal sexual excitement phase

Duration

≥6 months

Symptoms
  • Difficulties with orgasms
  • Delayed/reduced frequency of orgasms
  • Reduced intensity of orgasms

Diagnostic Criteria

≥1 symptom during most sexual encounters

Treatment

Psychotherapy

questions.text: A 7-year-old child assigned female at birth has been consistently expressing a strong desire to be a boy for the past 2.5 years. The child prefers traditionally masculine clothing, toys, and activities, and becomes upset when referred to as a girl. What is the most appropriate diagnosis according to the ICD-11 criteria?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ There is a marked incongruence between the child's experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex.
  • ↳ The child shows a strong desire to be a different gender than the assigned sex.
  • ↳ The child exhibits preferences for clothes, toys, and activities typical of the experienced gender.
  • ↳ The duration of symptoms (2.5 years) exceeds the requirement of 2 years.
  • ↳ The child shows distress when gender identity is not acknowledged (upset when referred to as a girl).
  • ↳ The child is prepubertal.
  • ↳ According to ICD-11 , gender dysphoria has been classified into:
  • ↳ ICD-11
  • ↳ Gender incongruence of adolescence or adulthood (Option C) : A marked incongruence between an individual's experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex, lasting at least 6 months, manifesting in adolescence or adulthood. Gender incongruence of childhood: A marked incongruence between a child's experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex, lasting at least 6 months, manifesting before puberty onset. Gender incongruence, unspecified: A condition where an individual experiences a mismatch between their gender identity and assigned sex, without specifying age of onset or meeting full diagnostic criteria.
  • ↳ Gender incongruence of adolescence or adulthood (Option C) : A marked incongruence between an individual's experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex, lasting at least 6 months, manifesting in adolescence or adulthood.
  • ↳ Gender incongruence of adolescence or adulthood
  • ↳ (Option C)
  • ↳ :
  • ↳ Gender incongruence of childhood: A marked incongruence between a child's experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex, lasting at least 6 months, manifesting before puberty onset.
  • ↳ Gender incongruence of childhood:
  • ↳ Gender incongruence, unspecified: A condition where an individual experiences a mismatch between their gender identity and assigned sex, without specifying age of onset or meeting full diagnostic criteria.
  • ↳ Gender incongruence, unspecified:
  • ↳ Previously in ICD-10 , gender dysphoria consisted of:
  • ↳ ICD-10
  • ↳ Transsexualism (Option A): Desire to live as the opposite sex, often seeking surgery and hormone therapy. Dual-role transvestism (Option B): Cross-dressing without a desire for permanent sex change. Gender identity disorder of childhood : Persistent discomfort with one's gender starting in childhood.
  • ↳ Transsexualism (Option A): Desire to live as the opposite sex, often seeking surgery and hormone therapy.
  • ↳ Transsexualism (Option A):
  • ↳ Dual-role transvestism (Option B): Cross-dressing without a desire for permanent sex change.
  • ↳ Dual-role transvestism (Option B):
  • ↳ Gender identity disorder of childhood : Persistent discomfort with one's gender starting in childhood.
  • ↳ :

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the psychiatric clinic with distressing thoughts and behaviors involving intense sexual arousal from observing unsuspecting individuals in private settings. He reports that he has experienced these urges for several years and has acted on them multiple times, which has caused legal and interpersonal problems. Which of the following paraphilias best fits his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Disorders of Sexual Preference (Paraphilias/Perversions):
  • ↳ Fetishism (Option C) In fetishism, sexual interest centers on objects (such as shoes, gloves, or stockings) closely linked to the human body, or on non-genital body parts. The latter focus is sometimes called partialism. Exclusively found in men. Exhibitionism (Option B) Exhibitionism is the recurrent urge to expose the genitals to a stranger or an unsuspecting person. Almost exclusively found in men. Transvestism/ Eonism Previously known as transvestic fetishism. Trans means opposite and vest means clothes Persons dressing in opposite gender clothes for sexual pleasure. Frotteurism Characterized by a man rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman to achieve orgasm. Voyeurism Persistent focus on fantasies and behaviors involving the observation of unaware individuals who are nude or involved in sexual activities Also known as scopophilia Masochism (Option D) Recurrent sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer. Sadism Recurrent sexual arousal from the physical or psychological suffering of another person. Pedophilia Pedophilia involves recurrent intense sexual urges toward, or arousal by, children. As per DSM-5, the child must be under 14 years old, and the patient must be at least 16 years old and at least five years older than the victims. Other paraphilic disorders Necrophilia: Obtaining sexual gratification from corpses/cadavers. Zoophilia: Sexual arousal from animals. Telephone and computer scatologia: Sexual arousal involving obscene phone calls or obscene messages/images to unsuspecting persons. Coprophilia: Sexual pleasure associated with desire to defecate on a partner/to be defecated on/eat feces. Urophilia: Sexual pleasure associated with desire to urinate on a partner/to be urinated on. Klismaphilia: Use of enemas for sexual stimulation.
  • ↳ Fetishism (Option C) In fetishism, sexual interest centers on objects (such as shoes, gloves, or stockings) closely linked to the human body, or on non-genital body parts. The latter focus is sometimes called partialism. Exclusively found in men.

  • ↳ Treatment: Psychotherapy - Cognitive Behavior Therapy (CBT)
  • ↳ Treatment:

Fetishism

(Option C)
  • In fetishism, sexual interest centers on objects (such as shoes, gloves, or stockings) closely linked to the human body, or on non-genital body parts.
  • The latter focus is sometimes called partialism.
  • Exclusively found in men.

Exhibitionism

(Option B)
  • Exhibitionism is the recurrent urge to expose the genitals to a stranger or an unsuspecting person.
  • Almost exclusively found in men.

Transvestism/

Eonism
  • Previously known as transvestic fetishism. Trans means opposite and vest means clothes
  • Persons dressing in opposite gender clothes for sexual pleasure.

Frotteurism
  • Characterized by a man rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman to achieve orgasm.

Voyeurism
  • Persistent focus on fantasies and behaviors involving the observation of unaware individuals who are nude or involved in sexual activities
  • Also known as scopophilia

Masochism

(Option D)
  • Recurrent sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer.

Sadism
  • Recurrent sexual arousal from the physical or psychological suffering of another person.

Pedophilia
  • Pedophilia involves recurrent intense sexual urges toward, or arousal by, children.
  • As per DSM-5, the child must be under 14 years old, and the patient must be at least 16 years old and at least five years older than the victims.

Other paraphilic disorders
  • Necrophilia: Obtaining sexual gratification from corpses/cadavers.
  • Zoophilia: Sexual arousal from animals.
  • Telephone and computer scatologia: Sexual arousal involving obscene phone calls or obscene messages/images to unsuspecting persons.
  • Coprophilia: Sexual pleasure associated with desire to defecate on a partner/to be defecated on/eat feces.
  • Urophilia: Sexual pleasure associated with desire to urinate on a partner/to be urinated on.
  • Klismaphilia: Use of enemas for sexual stimulation.

questions.text: Which of the following paraphilias involves sexual arousal from interaction with corpses?
Which of the following sexual pain disorders involves painful intercourse due to involuntary muscle spasms in the pelvic floor?
